docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: Subdivision 1 Institution of appeals and cross-appeals [rr 51.16, 51.17]

heading.title: Subdivision 1 Institution of appeals and cross-appeals [rr 51.16, 51.17]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: Subdivision 1 Institution of appeals and cross-appeals [rr 51.16, 51.17]
[r 51.16] r 51.16 Time for filing and service of notice of appeal (cf SCR Part 51, rules 5 and 6(1) and (3))

leg:heading.title: Time for filing and service of notice of appeal (cf SCR Part 51, rules 5 and 6(1) and (3))

p.text: A notice of appeal must be filed and served on each necessary party:
if the notice of appeal is filed pursuant to leave to appeal— within 7 days after leave is given or such other time as the Court may fix, or
if a notice of intention to appeal has been filed and served under this Part and the notice of appeal is not filed pursuant to leave — as allowed under rule 51.9 , or

if a notice of intention to appeal has not been filed and served under this Part and the notice of appeal is not filed pursuant to leave to appeal — within 28 days after the material date or such other time as the Court may fix.
Rule 51.20 requires any notice of appeal to specify a return day.
A person who files and serves a notice of appeal must also file or lodge a copy of the notice with the court below — see rule 51.42 .
The Court may extend time under subrule (1)(a) or (c) at any time.
Rule 51.9 provides for the extension of the time for the filing and service of a relevant originating process when a notice of intention to appeal has been filed and served under this Part.
A party applying for an extension under subrule (1)(a) or (c) must lodge and serve the draft notice of appeal with the application.
The approved form for notice of appeal (Court of Appeal) is Form 105.
The time limits for various proceedings in the Court of Appeal are summarised in [51.1.3] .

There are no specified criteria, either in the present rule or in the general case management criteria in CPA ss 56–60, for the exercise of the discretion to extend time for the institution of an appeal. Consequently, the discretion requires an assessment of the interests of justice in the particular case, and necessarily permits consideration of a wide range of considerations: Hughes v National Trustees Executors & Agency Co of Australasia Ltd [1978] VR 257 at 262 . Decisions involving such a broadly stated discretion will inevitably be influenced by both the actual circumstances under consideration and by prevailing judicial perceptions about the appropriate balance between expedition, cost, efficiency and fairness. This latter influence can be particularly seen in some of the older authorities which, occurring in a different environment and perhaps influenced by differently worded discretionary powers, tended to require something in the nature of “special” circumstances before regarding an extension of time as appropriate: Re Helsby [1894] 1 QB 742 ; International Financial Society v City of Moscow Gas Co (1877) 7 Ch D 241 ; Re Manchester Economic Building Society (1883) 24 Ch D 488 ; Re Coles [1907] 1 KB 1 (mistake by a legal adviser as to the time for appeal — extension refused); Craig v Phillips (1887) 7 Ch D 249 (application lodged after expiry of a long appeal period and in reliance upon a subsequent decision — extension refused); Re Padstow Total Loss and Collision Assurance Assn (1882) 20 Ch D 137; 51 LJ Ch 344 (application by a contributory not a party to the original winding up proceedings — extension granted); Ex parte Tucker (1879) 12 Ch D 308 (application by a creditor not a party to the original bankruptcy proceedings below — extension granted); Nanschild v Pratt [2011] NSWCA 85; BC201101957 at [37] and following (summons seeking leave to appeal filed 6 months after material date — slight prospects of obtaining leave to appeal — no extension); Blackmore v Browne [2011] NSWCA 114; BC201103234 (delay of 55 days — during period of court vacation time — absence of prejudice to respondents — extension granted); Krishna v Lovett [2011] NSWCA 354; BC201108930 (proposed appeal 17 months out of time — deliberate initial decision not to appeal initially — prejudice to respondent — lack of prospects of success — no extension).

level.toc-caption: [51.16.10] Extension of time — discretion exercisable to prevent injustice

heading.title: Extension of time — discretion exercisable to prevent injustice

p.text: The proper approach to the exercise of the discretion to extend time is simply to enquire whether the strict application of the rules will, or may, occasion injustice. This enquiry will involve consideration of the conduct of the parties, the nature of the litigation, and the consequences for the respective parties granting or refusing the application to extend time: Gallo v Dawson (1990) 93 ALR 479 at 480; 64 ALJR 458; BC9002940 per McHugh JA citing Avery v No 2 Public Service Appeal Board [1973] 2 NZLR 86 at 92 ; Jess v Scott (1986) 12 FCR 187 at 194-5; 70 ALR 185 ; Re Manchester Economic Building Society (1883) 24 Ch D 488 per Bowen LJ; Outboard Marine Australia Pty Ltd v Byrnes [1974] 1 NSWLR 27 ; Moulieux v Girvan NSW Pty Ltd (rec and mgr apptd) (NSWCA, Kirby P, Priestley and Handley JJA, No 40506/91, 20 September 1991, unreported, BC9101549). In that enquiry, weight may be given to:

the reason why the appeal was not lodged within time: the fact the reason for delay was a mistake or omission on the part of the appellant's legal advisers may also justify the granting of an extension of time: Gatti v Shoosmith [1934] Ch 841; Palata Investments Ltd v Burt and Sinfield Ltd [1985] 2 All ER 517; [1985] 1 WLR 942 ; Avery v No 2 Public Service Appeal Board [1973] 2 NZLR 86 at 91, 92 ; Stollznow v Calvert [1980] 2 NSWLR 749 ;

the period for which an extension is sought: the mere fact the extension is only sought for a small period may itself justify an extension of time, at least if the appeal raises a substantial issue and the delay has not caused relevant prejudice to the respondent: Danny Kidron and Andrew Spaile Architects Pty Ltd v Garrett (1994) 35 NSWLR 572; BC9403416 (appeal lodged several days out of time); Maitland v Nationwide News Pty Ltd [2004] NSWCA 155; BC200402704 (delay of seven weeks); Morris v Public Transport Commission of New South Wales (NSWCA, Moffitt P, Glass and Mahoney JJA, No 146/78, 28 May 1984, unreported, BC8400333) (time extended six years after an appeal was lodged one day out of time)); Jess v Scott , above (appeal lodged one day late); Salter Rex & Co v Ghosh [1971] 2 QB 597 at 601; [1971] 2 All ER 865 ).

the apparent prospects of success on the appeal (Gallo , above). It will generally be sufficient for the applicant to demonstrate a fairly arguable case without a detailed evaluation of the prospects of success of the proposed appeal: Tomko v Palasty (No 2) [2007] NSWCA 369; BC200710980 at [58] per Basten JA , at [17] per Ipp JA, agreeing. This generality assumes there is a reasonable explanation for delay and no significant prejudice to the opponent. Where either of those assumptions do not apply, the applicant for an extension of time is likely to be required to show that the proposed appeal has more than merely arguable prospects of success: Tomko v Palasty (No 2) at [14] per Hodgson JA, at [17] per Ipp JA agreeing (extension refused — deficiencies in the explanations offered).

level.toc-caption: [51.16.15] Extension of time — change in circumstances after trial

heading.title: Extension of time — change in circumstances after trial

p.text: Matters that have occurred after the judgment in the court below will not generally provide a basis for the extension of time: Murphy v Stone-Wallwork (Charlton) Ltd [1969] 2 All ER 949; [1969] 1 WLR 1023 at 1031 ; Barder v Barder [1986] 2 All ER 918; [1987] Fam 24 ; cf Jenkins v Livesey [1985] AC 424 . This restriction particularly applies where a later decision in another case throws doubt on the decision from which the appeal is sought to be made: Wilson v Liverpool City Council [1971] 1 All ER 628; [1971] 1 WLR 302 (subsequent House of Lords decision); Piening v Wanless (1968) 117 CLR 498 at 506; [1968] ALR 342; BC6800190 ; Eggins v Brooms Head Bowling & Recreational Club Ltd (1986) 5 NSWLR 521; (1986) Aust Torts Reports ¶80-044 ; Re Berkeley [1945]1 Ch 1; R v Unger [1977] 2 NSWLR 990 ; Re Wigfull [1919] 1 Ch 52 ; Property and Reversionary Investment Corp Ltd v Templar [1978] 2 All ER 433; [1977] 1 WLR 1223 . However, a retrospective legislative change may well provide a proper basis for an extension of time: Eyre v Wynn-Mackenzie [1896] 1 Ch 35.

level.toc-caption: [51.16.20] Extension of time — decisions made by parties and representatives

heading.title: Extension of time — decisions made by parties and representatives

p.text: Belated applications, requiring an extension of time, may sometimes be the result of changed circumstances. These may include altered assessments of the prospects of success, particularly where there has been a change in a party’s legal advice. Reconsideration of this kind, at least if it occurs in relation to some step in an otherwise timely appeal, may justify an extension of time for filing a notice of contention or notice of cross appeal. This will be particularly the case if the point sought to be raised derives directly from the matters already likely to be in contest in the appeal: Wyllie v Tarrison Pty Ltd [2007] NSWCA 95; BC200702836 at [6] per Hodgson JA. (It was accepted that different views held by counsel at different times may not be unreasonable. Leave refused — on ground that the cross-appeal had insufficient prospects of success). Apart from cases of that kind, exceptional circumstances are likely to be required before a court would substantially extend the time for lodging an appeal. Even an unrepresented party’s lack of legal knowledge, with its consequential difficulty and delay in making an informed assessment of the appeal’s prospects of success, is unlikely to provide a persuasive basis for a substantial extension of time: Gallo v Dawson (1990) 93 ALR 479 at 481; 64 ALJR 458; BC9002940 ; obiter per McHugh JA (the extension application was made over 16 months out of time without furnishing any details as to: the time spent in research; the nature of the research; when the decision to appeal was made. No claim was made of an unawareness of the time limit for lodging a notice of appeal. Leave refused — on ground that the appeal had no prospects of success. The decision was confirmed on appeal, see Gallo v Dawson (No 2) (1992) 109 ALR 319; 66 ALJR 859; BC9202668 ).

level.toc-caption: [51.16.25] Restrictions on the extension of time

heading.title: Restrictions on the extension of time

p.text: The power to extend time conferred by this rule must be read subject to any contrary indication in statutes conferring a right of appeal. If the statutory right of appeal is conditional on the notice of appeal being lodged within a specified time, that time cannot be extended under the present rule — at least not where the condition was imposed after the commencement of the general rights of appeal contained in the Supreme Court Act 1970 or the District Court Act 1973: Patterson v Public Service Board [1984] 1 NSWLR 237 (an appeal under Government and Related Employees Appeal Tribunal Act 1980 s 54): see also [51.7.5] . Compare David v National Panasonic (Aust) Pty Ltd (NSWCA, 23 September 1985, unreported) (an appeal under Compensation Court Act 1984 s 32, where it was held that there was power to extend time).
Legislation cited in [51.16.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 51.16(1).

A notice filed after the time specified in UCPR r 51.16(1) is nevertheless effective to institute an appeal. A respondent may rely on the delay to justify some ameliorating direction, and may even apply to have the proceedings dismissed because of the failure to comply with the rules: Morris v Public Transport Commission of New South Wales (NSWCA, Moffitt P, Glass and Mahoney JJA, No 146/78, 28 May 1984, unreported, BC8400333). In the absence of any such order being made, the appellant is entitled to have the appeal proceed to a hearing.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 51.17] r 51.17 Filing and service of notice of cross-appeal (cf SCR Part 51, rule 18)

leg:heading.title: Filing and service of notice of cross-appeal (cf SCR Part 51, rule 18)

p.text: A respondent who wishes to seek the discharge or variation of the decision below (or part of the decision below) may file and serve a notice of cross-appeal.

A respondent to an appeal who is entitled to cross-appeal should file a notice of cross-appeal only if the respondent wishes to vary the decision below. If the respondent wishes to have the decision below affirmed on grounds other than those relied on by the court below, the respondent should file and serve a notice of contention as provided by rule 51.40 rather than a notice of cross-appeal. If the respondent objects to the competency of the appeal, the respondent should file and serve a notice of objection to the competency of the appeal as provided by rule 51.41 .
A notice of cross-appeal must be filed and served on each necessary party:
if the notice of cross-appeal is filed pursuant to leave to cross-appeal — within 7 days after leave to cross-appeal is given or such other time as the Court may fix, or
in any other case — within:
14 days after the filing of a summons seeking leave to appeal or a notice of appeal, whichever is the earlier, or
such other time as the Court may fix.
A person who files and serves a notice of cross-appeal must also file or lodge a copy of the notice with the court below—see rule 51.42 .
The Court may extend time under subrule (2)(a) or (b)(ii) at any time.
Rule 51.9 provides for the extension of the time for the filing and service of a relevant originating process when a notice of intention to appeal has been filed and served under this Part.
A party applying for an extension under subrule (2) must lodge and serve the draft notice of cross-appeal with the application.

level.toc-caption: [51.17.5] Cross-appeal — desirability of determining all issues

heading.title: Cross-appeal — desirability of determining all issues

p.text: Trial judges are encouraged to determine all material issues raised in the proceedings, not just those that are directly dispositive of the proceedings. A trial judge’s adherence to this convention may facilitate appropriate orders being made in the event of a successful appeal and, in that event, will significantly reduce the ultimate delay and costs involved in the proceedings: see [36.2.40] . The same kinds of considerations make it desirable for any intermediate appeal court to determine all reasonably arguable grounds that are raised in a cross-appeal: Jones v R (1989) 166 CLR 409; 84 ALR 193 (new trial ordered without determining ground relied on to support complete acquittal); Bank of South Australia Ltd v Ferguson (1998) 192 CLR 248 at 263; 151 ALR 729; [1998] HCA 12; BC9800309 (appeal allowed and cross-appeal remitted for determination by the Supreme Court).

level.toc-caption: [51.17.10] Cross appeal only during pending appeal

heading.title: Cross appeal only during pending appeal

p.text: Only a respondent to an appeal can bring a cross-appeal. Once an appeal is disposed of by a final judgment of the court, there is no longer an appeal on foot and a cross-appeal cannot be filed: Tomko v Palasty (No 2) [2007] NSWCA 369; BC200710980 at [2], [30] (the fact that the respondent wished to challenge dismissal by a registrar of an application to cross-appeal out of time was not brought to the court’s attention on hearing the appeal).
